Name: Calling on President Obama to grant clemency to Oscar López Rivera.
Title: Resolution calling on President Obama to grant clemency to Oscar López Rivera so that he is immediately released from prison, as his continued incarceration is unjust and serves no legitimate purpose.
BodyName: Committee on State and Federal Legislation

History.Action: Hearing on P-C Item by Comm
History.Description: This Resolution was Hearing on P-C Item by Comm
History.BodyName: Committee on State and Federal Legislation

History.Description: A motion was made that this Resolution be P-C Item Approved by Comm approved by Roll Call.
History.BodyName: Committee on State and Federal Legislation

History.Description: This Resolution was Introduced by Council
This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
History.AgendaNote: Precosidered - Adopted by the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
History.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 8 Council Members formally voted against this item: 
Council Members Gentile, Lancman, Matteo, Ulrich, Vacca, Vallone, Weprin, and Ignizio.



The following 2 Council Members formally abstained to vote on this item:  
Council Members Cohen and Garodnick.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.

Attachments.Name: June 10, 2015 - Stated Meeting Agenda with Links to Files
Minutes of the Stated Meeting - June 10, 2015

Text:
By Council Members Mendez, The Speaker (Council Member Mark-Viverito), Rodriguez, Chin and Wills 

      Whereas, Oscar L�pez Rivera was born in Puerto Rico in 1943; and
      Whereas, Oscar L�pez Rivera moved with his family to Chicago as an adolescent; and
      Whereas, Oscar L�pez Rivera is a decorated Vietnam War veteran; and
      Whereas, During his tour of service in Vietnam, L�pez Rivera's unit was securing the perimeter of a town to ensure its safety during an election when  the unit unwittingly entered a mine field where many of his fellow soldiers began to sustain serious injuries; and
      Whereas, Instead of running for cover, L�pez Rivera tended to the wounded and cleared a space for helicopters to land to evacuate them; and 
      Whereas, On that day, L�pez Rivera refused to leave his friends behind, and for this act of valor he was awarded the Bronze Star; and 
      Whereas, It is this dedication to community, friends and family that would become a hallmark of L�pez Rivera's life;
      Whereas, When L�pez Rivera returned home from the war he found his community wracked by drugs, poverty, substandard housing and blight; and 
      Whereas, Once again, L�pez Rivera refused to run and instead became an activist, fighting to improve conditions for his family, his Puerto Rican community, and the Latino community of Chicago; and
      Whereas, As a community activist, L�pez Rivera helped found La Escuelita Puertorrique�a, now known as the Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos High School and the Juan Antonio Corretjer Puerto Rican Cultural Center. He became a community organizer for the Northwest Community Organization, ASPIRA, ASSPA, and the 1st Congregational Church of Chicago. He helped to found FREE, a half-way house for convicted drug addicts, and ALAS, an educational program for Latino prisoners at Stateville Prison in Illinois. L�pez Rivera also worked to establish bilingual education in public schools and pressured universities to recruit Latino students and faculty. Perhaps most significantly, L�pez Rivera struggled to end discrimination against minority communities; and
      Whereas, L�pez Rivera also fervently believed in Puerto Rican independence, and was critical of the U.S. government's role in the governance of Puerto Rico; and 
      Whereas, Between 1981 and 1983 L�pez Rivera and 13 other men and women involved in the movement for Puerto Rican independence were convicted of seditious conspiracy; and  
      Whereas, In 1981, L�pez Rivera was sentenced to 55 years in prison; and
      Whereas, L�pez Rivera has consistently maintained that he was not involved in any acts that harmed anyone or took a life; and
      Whereas, L�pez Rivera's sentence was greatly disproportionate to the offense for which he was convicted; and 
      Whereas, In 1988, L�pez Rivera was convicted of conspiracy to escape prison and sentenced to an additional 15 years in prison to be served consecutively to his original sentence; and
      Whereas, This sentence was also greatly disproportionate to the offense for which L�pez Rivera was convicted; and
      Whereas, In addition, L�pez Rivera was made to serve over 12 years of this sentence in  solitary confinement, meaning he was confined to a  closet-sized cell for 23 hours a day with no human contact; and
      Whereas, In 1999, President Bill Clinton, offered to commute L�pez Rivera's sentence as well as the sentences of all but two of his co-defendants; and
      Whereas, In explaining his decision to offer clemency, President Clinton noted that L�pez Rivera was never convicted of specific crimes that resulted in deaths or injuries nor was he ever convicted of any act of violence; and
      Whereas, President Clinton also noted that "our society believes that a punishment should fit the crime;" and
      Whereas, President Clinton concluded that the sentences received by L�pez Rivera and his co-defendants were "out of proportion to their crimes"; and
      Whereas, Once again, L�pez Rivera refused to leave any member of his community behind and therefore declined the President's offer of clemency; and
      Whereas, Had L�pez Rivera accepted President Clinton's clemency offer, he would have been released from prison in 2009; and      
      Whereas, Oscar L�pez Rivera has now served over 33 years in prison; and
      Whereas, L�pez Rivera has served more time in prison than Nelson Mandela; and 
      Whereas, Many prominent politicians and world leaders including Coretta Scott King, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, former President Jimmy Carter, many Nobel Peace Prize Laureates and others have called for L�pez Rivera to be released from prison; and
      Whereas, The movement to release L�pez Rivera has become a unifying force, bringing together people of widely diverse backgrounds and political and social beliefs; and 
      Whereas, In 2013, Archbishop Desmond Tutu said of L�pez Rivera's continued imprisonment, "In any case or interpretation, justice cannot be served by keeping Oscar L�pez Rivera in prison. Now is the time for his immediate and unconditional release;" and
      Whereas, The United Nations Decolonization Committee has passed a resolution every year since 2001 calling for L�pez Rivera's release; and   
      Whereas, The Congressional Hispanic Caucus recently sent a letter to President Obama urging him to commute L�pez Rivera's sentence and "grant his immediate release from prison"; and
      Whereas, In 2013, Alejandro Garc�a Padilla, Governor of Puerto Rico, called on President Obama to commute L�pez Rivera's prison sentence saying, "We see Mr. L�pez Rivera's release as an issue that must rise above partisan affiliations and status preferences. It is an issue that touches basic issues of humanity, justice and compassion. It is an issue that relates to principles that you certainly share with us. Thirty-two years in prison for Mr. L�pez Rivera is just enough. I ask - Mr. President - that you exercise your constitutional power of pardon to commute his sentence and grant his release;" and
      Whereas, Religious leaders including Metropolitan Archbishop of San Juan, Puerto Rico, Roberto Gonz�lez Nieves,  and Reverend Geoffrey A. Black, General Minister and President, United Church of Christ have called for L�pez Rivera's release; and
      Whereas, National labor organizations including the AFL-CIO, AFSCME and SEIU have called for L�pez Rivera to be released; and  
      Whereas, Supporters have sent tens of thousands of letters to the President calling for L�pez Rivera's immediate release from prison; and 
      Whereas, New York City is the home of the largest Puerto Rican community outside of Puerto Rico; and
      Whereas, There is overwhelming support in New York City's Puerto Rican community for L�pez Rivera's immediate release; and
      Whereas, In January of this year, L�pez Rivera celebrated his 72 nd birthday; and
      Whereas, L�pez Rivera's official release date is in 2023, when he will be 80 years old; and
      Whereas, All of the other men and women sent to prison along with L�pez Rivera have since been released and are leading productive and responsible lives; and 
      Whereas, L�pez Rivera is a dedicated father, grandfather, friend, decorated war veteran and community activist; and
      Whereas, Despite the length of time he has spent in prison and the over 12 years he spent in isolation, L�pez Rivera has not lost his spirit or his profound humanity; and
      Whereas, It is time for L�pez Rivera to be set free; now, therefore, be it
      Resolved, That the Council calls upon President Obama to grant clemency to Oscar L�pez Rivera so that he is immediately released from prison, as his continued incarceration is unjust and serves no legitimate purpose. 


	

1

\v0\par
By Council Members Mendez, The Speaker (Council Member Mark-Viverito), Rodriguez, Chin and Wills \par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1 Whereas, Oscar L\'f3pez Rivera was born in Puerto Rico in 1943; and\par
Whereas, Oscar L\'f3pez Rivera moved with his family to Chicago as an adolescent; and\par
Whereas, Oscar L\'f3pez Rivera is a decorated Vietnam War veteran; and\par
Whereas, During his tour of service in Vietnam, L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s unit was securing the perimeter of a town to ensure its safety during an election when  the unit unwittingly entered a mine field where many of his fellow soldiers began to sustain serious injuries; and\par
Whereas, Instead of running for cover, L\'f3pez Rivera tended to the wounded and cleared a space for helicopters to land to evacuate them; and \par
Whereas, On that day, L\'f3pez Rivera refused to leave his friends behind, and for this act of valor he was awarded the Bronze Star; and \par
Whereas, It is this dedication to community, friends and family that would become a hallmark of L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s life;\par
Whereas, When L\'f3pez Rivera returned home from the war he found his community wracked by drugs, poverty, substandard housing and blight; and \par
Whereas, Once again, L\'f3pez Rivera refused to run and instead became an activist, fighting to improve conditions for his family, his Puerto Rican community, and the Latino community of Chicago; and\par
Whereas, As a community activist, \cf1 L\'f3pez Rivera helped found La Escuelita Puertorrique\'f1a, now known as the Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos High School and the Juan Antonio Corretjer Puerto Rican Cultural Center. He became a community organizer for the Northwest Community Organization, ASPIRA, ASSPA, and the 1st Congregational Church of Chicago. He helped to found FREE, a half-way house for convicted drug addicts, and ALAS, an educational program for Latino prisoners at Stateville Prison in Illinois\f1\fs21 .\cf0\f0\fs24  L\'f3pez Rivera also worked to establish bilingual education in public schools and pressured universities to recruit Latino students and faculty. Perhaps most significantly, L\'f3pez Rivera struggled to end discrimination against minority communities; and\par
Whereas, L\'f3pez Rivera also fervently believed in Puerto Rican independence, and was critical of the U.S. government\rquote s role in the governance of Puerto Rico; and \par
Whereas, Between 1981 and 1983 L\'f3pez Rivera and 13 other men and women involved in the movement for Puerto Rican independence were convicted of seditious conspiracy; and  \par
Whereas, In 1981, L\'f3pez Rivera was sentenced to 55 years in prison; and\par
Whereas, L\'f3pez\cf2  Rivera has consistently maintained that he was not involved in any acts that harmed anyone or took a life; and\par
Whereas, \cf0 L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s\cf2  sentence was greatly disproportionate to the offense for which he was convicted; and \cf0\par
Whereas, In 1988, L\'f3pez Rivera was convicted of conspiracy to escape prison and sentenced to an additional 15 years in prison to be served consecutively to his original sentence; and\par
Whereas, This sentence was also greatly disproportionate to the offense for which L\'f3pez Rivera was convicted; and\par
Whereas, In addition, L\'f3pez Rivera was made to serve over 12 years of this sentence in  solitary confinement, meaning he was confined to a  closet-sized cell for 23 hours a day with no human contact; and\par
Whereas, In 1999,\cf1  President Bill Clinton,\cf0  offered to commute L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s sentence as well as the sentences of all but two of his co-defendants; and\par
\cf1 Whereas, In explaining his decision to offer clemency, President Clinton \cf0 noted that\cf1\f1\fs21  \f0\fs24 L\'f3pez Rivera was never convicted of specific crimes that resulted in deaths or injuries nor was he ever convicted of any act of violence; and\par
Whereas, President Clinton also noted that \ldblquote our society believes that a punishment should fit the crime;\rdblquote  and\par
\cf0 Whereas, \cf1 President \cf0\fs22 Clinton concluded \cf1\fs24 that the sentences received by L\'f3pez Rivera and his co-defendants were "out of proportion to their crimes\rdblquote ; and\par
W\cf0 hereas, Once again, L\'f3pez Rivera refused to leave any member of his community behind and therefore declined the President\rquote s offer of clemency; and\par
Whereas, Had L\'f3pez Rivera accepted President Clinton\rquote s clemency offer, he would have been released from prison in 2009; and      \par
Whereas, Oscar L\'f3pez Rivera has now served over 33 years in prison; and\par
Whereas, L\'f3pez Rivera has served more time in prison than Nelson Mandela; and \par
Whereas, Many prominent politicians and world leaders including Coretta Scott King, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, former President Jimmy Carter, many Nobel Peace Prize Laureates and others have called for L\'f3pez Rivera to be released from prison; and\par
Whereas, The movement to release L\'f3pez Rivera has become a unifying force, bringing together people of widely diverse backgrounds and political and social beliefs; and \par
Whereas, In 2013, Archbishop Desmond Tutu said of L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s continued imprisonment, \ldblquote In any case or interpretation, justice cannot be served by keeping Oscar L\'f3pez Rivera in prison. Now is the time for his immediate and unconditional release;\rdblquote  and\par
Whereas, The United Nations Decolonization Committee has passed a resolution every year since 2001 calling for L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s release; and   \par
\fs26 Whereas, The Congressional Hispanic Caucus recently sent a letter to President Obama urging him to commute L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s sentence and \ldblquote grant his immediate release from prison\rdblquote ; and\f1\fs21\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\cf2\f0\fs24 Whereas, In 2013, Alejandro Garc\'eda Padilla, Governor of Puerto Rico, called on President Obama to commute\cf0\fs26  L\'f3pez Rivera\cf2\fs24\rquote s prison sentence saying, \ldblquote\cf0\fs26 We see Mr. L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s release as an issue that must rise above partisan affiliations and status preferences. It is an issue that touches basic issues of humanity, justice and compassion. It is an issue that relates to principles that you certainly share with us. Thirty-two years in prison for Mr. L\'f3pez Rivera is just enough. I ask - Mr. President - that you exercise your constitutional power of pardon to commute his sentence and grant his release;\rdblquote  and\par
Whereas, Religious leaders including \cf2\fs24 Metropolitan Archbishop of San Juan, Puerto Rico, Roberto Gonz\'e1lez Nieves,  and Reverend Geoffrey A. Black, General Minister and President, United Church of Christ have called for L\cf0\fs26\'f3\cf2\fs24 pez Rivera\rquote s release; and\par
Whereas, National labor organizations including the AFL-CIO, AFSCME and SEIU have called for L\cf0\fs26\'f3\cf2\fs24 pez Rivera to be released; and  \par
\cf0\fs26 Whereas, Supporters have sent tens of thousands of letters to the President calling for L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s immediate release from prison; and \par
Whereas, New York City is the home of the largest Puerto Rican community outside of Puerto Rico; and\par
Whereas, There is overwhelming support in New York City\rquote s Puerto Rican community for L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s immediate release; and\par
Whereas, In January of this year, \cf2\fs24 L\'f3pez Rivera \cf0\fs26 celebrated his 72\super  nd\nosupersub  birthday; and\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\fs24 Whereas, L\'f3pez Rivera\rquote s official release date is in 2023, when he will be 80 years old; and\par
\fs26 Whereas, All of the other men and women sent to prison along with \cf2\fs24 L\'f3pez Rivera \cf0\fs26 have since been released and are leading productive and responsible lives; and \par
Whereas, \cf2\fs24 L\'f3pez\cf0\fs26  Rivera is a dedicated father, grandfather, friend, decorated war veteran and community activist; and\par
Whereas, Despite the length of time he has spent in prison and the over 12 years he spent in isolation, \cf2\fs24 L\'f3pez Rivera\cf0\fs26  has not lost his spirit or his profound humanity; and\fs24\par
Whereas, It is time for L\'f3pez Rivera to be set free; now, therefore, be it\par
Resolved, That the Council calls upon President Obama to grant clemency to Oscar L\'f3pez Rivera so that he is immediately released from prison, as his continued incarceration is unjust and serves no legitimate purpose. \par
\pard\ltrpar\fs22\par
\pard\cbpat3\ltrpar\qc\fs24\par
